column1: The City of Randwick is a local government area in the eastern suburbs of Sydney
column4: Randwick is the second-oldest local government area in New South Wales
column5: after the City of Sydney. It comprises an area of 36 square kilometres (14 sq mi) and as at the 2016 census had a population of 140
column6: 660.The Mayor of the City of Randwick is Cr. Danny Said

Indigenous Australian history in the area dates back tens of thousands of years. The local people at the time of colonisation were the Cadigal of the Dharug language group. European settlement led to the deaths of many Cadigal via introduced diseases or in conflict with settlers. The surviving Cadigal left the area or were pushed to the fringes of settlement. By the mid-nineteenth century
column2: the original tribal groupings had been effectively destroyed.

column1: The name Randwick comes from the village of Randwick in Gloucestershire
column3: birthplace of the district's first mayor Simeon Henry Pearce. The area was home to a few wealthy landowners and the poor residents of several shantytowns until the 1880s
column4: when the coming of trams from Sydney brought extensive suburban development. This development continued steadily
column5: with new tram lines (long since demolished) opening up most of the city for subdivision by the early 1900s. The New South Wales University of Technology opened at Kensington in 1949 on the site of Kensington Racecourse
column6: eventually becoming the University of New South Wales.

column1: A 2015 review of local government boundaries recommended that the City of Randwick merge with the Waverley and Woollahra councils to form a new council with an area of 58 square kilometres (22 sq mi) and support a population of approximately 274
column3: in May 2016 the NSW Government sought to dismiss the Council and force its amalgamation with Woollahra and Waverley councils. Woollahra Council instigated legal action claiming that there was procedural unfairness and that a KPMG report at the centre of merger proposals had been "misleading". The matter was heard before the NSW Court of Appeal who
column6: finding no merit in its arguments that the proposed merger with Waverley and Randwick councils was invalid. In July 2017
column7: the Berejiklian government decided to abandon the forced merger of the Woollahra
column8: Waverley and Randwick local government areas
column9: along with several other proposed forced mergers.

column3: 660 people in the Randwick local government area
column4: of these 49.2% were male and 50.8% were female. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people made up 1.5% of the population; significantly below the NSW and Australian averages of 2.9 and 2.8 per cent respectively. The median age of people in the City of Randwick was 34 years. Children aged 0â€“14 years made up 14.9% of the population and people aged 65 years and over made up 13.4% of the population. Of people in the area aged 15 years and over
column5: 38.5% were married and 9.1% were either divorced or separated.Population growth in the City of Randwick between the 2001 Census and the 2006 census was 1.10%; and in the subsequent five years to the 2011 census
column6: population growth was 7.59%. When compared with total population growth of Australia for the same periods
column8: population growth in Randwick local government area was lower than the national average. The median weekly income for residents within the City of Randwick was higher than the national average.

column1: Randwick City Council is composed of fifteen Councillors elected proportionally as five separate wards
column2: each electing three Councillors. All Councillors are elected for a fixed four-year term of office. The Mayor is elected for a two-year term
column3: with the Deputy Mayor for one year
column4: by the Councillors at the first meeting of the Council. The most recent election was held on 9 September 2017

column1: The City of Randwick has a number of heritage-listed sites
column2: including those listed under the New South Wales Heritage Register:
46 Adina Avenue: La Perouse Mission Church
1-39 Bunnerong Road: Chinese Market Gardens (La Perouse)
1250 Anzac Parade: Long Bay Correctional Centre
